subtopic: Physical Applications of Integration
content: Physical applications of integration use definite integrals to compute real-world quantities that accumulate continuously. Instead of summing discrete pieces, integration adds infinitely many tiny contributions. Common applications include mass from density, work done by a variable force, and fluid pressure. The unifying idea is accumulation: small pieces are modeled, summed, and then refined through limits to obtain exact results.

subtopic: Physical Applications of Integration
content: To find the mass of a rod with varying density, we integrate the density function over the rod’s length.

subtopic: Physical Applications of Integration
content: Ask: what small quantity is being added repeatedly?

subtopic: Physical Applications of Integration
content: Using formulas without identifying the correct small element leads to wrong integrals.

subtopic: Physical Applications of Integration
content: Integration models continuous accumulation in physical systems.

subtopic: Mass from Linear Density
content: When an object has varying density along its length, mass cannot be found by simple multiplication. Instead, we use a linear density function that describes mass per unit length. Each small segment contributes a tiny amount of mass, and integrating the density over the object’s length gives the total mass.

subtopic: Mass from Linear Density
content: A rod with density sin(x) over an interval has mass equal to the integral of sin(x) across that interval.

subtopic: Mass from Linear Density
content: Density multiplied by a small length gives a small mass.

subtopic: Mass from Linear Density
content: Treating variable density as constant produces incorrect results.

subtopic: Mass from Linear Density
content: Mass equals the integral of linear density.

subtopic: Work Done by a Variable Force
content: Work measures the energy required to move an object. When force varies with position, work is found by integrating the force over the distance traveled. Each small displacement contributes a tiny amount of work, and the total work is their sum.

subtopic: Work Done by a Variable Force
content: Stretching a spring requires more force as it stretches further, so total work is found by integrating the force function.

subtopic: Work Done by a Variable Force
content: Work is force times distance, summed continuously.

subtopic: Work Done by a Variable Force
content: Using constant-force formulas for variable forces is incorrect.

subtopic: Work Done by a Variable Force
content: Variable force work is found using integration.

subtopic: Moments
content: A moment measures how mass is distributed relative to a reference point or axis. Intuitively, it captures the tendency of mass to cause rotation. In one dimension, a moment is found by multiplying mass by its distance from the reference point.

subtopic: Moments
content: Two equal masses placed at equal distances on opposite sides of the origin produce moments that cancel.

subtopic: Moments
content: Think of a seesaw balancing about a pivot.

subtopic: Moments
content: Ignoring sign (left vs right of origin) gives wrong moments.

subtopic: Moments
content: Moments quantify mass distribution about a point.

subtopic: Center of Mass on a Line
content: The center of mass is the balance point of a system. For objects along a line, it is found by dividing the total moment by the total mass. This point represents where the entire mass could be concentrated without changing the system’s balance.

subtopic: Center of Mass on a Line
content: If heavier masses are farther from the origin, the center of mass shifts toward them.

subtopic: Center of Mass on a Line
content: Heavier masses pull the balance point closer.

subtopic: Center of Mass on a Line
content: Averaging positions without weights is incorrect.

subtopic: Center of Mass on a Line
content: Center of mass equals moment divided by total mass.

subtopic: Center of Mass of a Lamina
content: For thin plates with uniform density, the center of mass depends only on shape. Integration is used to compute moments about both axes, and dividing these moments by total mass gives the coordinates of the centroid.

subtopic: Center of Mass of a Lamina
content: A triangular lamina balances at a point closer to its wider base than its tip.

subtopic: Center of Mass of a Lamina
content: Use symmetry whenever possible to simplify calculations.

subtopic: Center of Mass of a Lamina
content: Forgetting to divide moments by total mass gives incorrect coordinates.

subtopic: Center of Mass of a Lamina
content: Centroids are found from moments and total mass.
